ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: What is respondent's relationship to the child participant?
Notes: 1= Mother; 2= Father; 3= Grandmother ; 4= Grandfather; 5= Brother; 6= Sister; 7= Aunt; 8= Uncle; 9= Nanny/child-minder; 10= Other

ElementDescription: If the respondent's relationship to the child participant is ''other'', describe:
In an average week, how many days does the child participant live with the caregiver?
What is the caregiver's current marital /relationship status?
Notes: 1= Married; 2= Divorced; 3= Single (never married); 4= Widowed; 6= Separated; 7= Not married but in a marriage like relationship (i.e. living together)

ElementDescription: What is your (participant's biological mother's) marital status?
Notes: 1= Single (never married); 2= Not married, but in a marriage like relationship (i.e. living together); 3= Married; 4= Divorced; 5= Widowed

ElementDescription: Does the caregiver's partner live with the child for at least 6 months out of the year in total? Or is there a secondary caregiver actively involved in the child's life?
How far did you (the child's biological mother) get in school?
Notes: 0= No education; 1= Completed Grade 1 (Sub A) to Grade 5 (Standard 3); 2= Completed Grade 6 (Standard 4) to Grade 7 (Standard 5); 3= Completed Grade 8 (Standard 6) to Grade 11 (Standard 9) i.e. High school without matriculating; 4= Completed Grade 12 (Standard 10) i.e. high school with matriculating; 5= Part of university/college/post-matric education; 6= Completed university/college/post-matric education; -1= Unknown

ElementDescription: What is your (the child's biological mother's) current employment status?
Notes: 1= Working now; 2= Self-employed; 3= Looking for work: Unemployed; 4= Temporarily Laid off; 5= Homemaker; 6= Student; 7= Illness/sickness; 8= Disabled; 99= Other

ElementDescription: What is your (the child's biological mother's) current employment status? If other, specify
Have you/the child's mother ever attended school?
What is your/the child's mother's highest level of education?
Notes: 111= Pre-school; 1= Class 1; 2= Class 2; 3= Class 3; 4= Class 4; 5= Class 5; 6= Class 6; 7= Class 7; 8= Class 8; 9= Form 1; 10= Form 2; 11= Form 3; 12= Form 4; 18= Tertiary Education; 100= Non-academic curriculum; 101= Alternative curriculum e.g. IGCSE; 999= Other; 888= Refused to answer; 777= Unknown

ElementDescription: What is your/the child's mother's highest level of education? If level of education is Other, Describe:
What is the child participant's caregiver's highest level of education?
Notes: 0= No education; 1= Completed Grade 1 to Grade 5 (Sub A - Standard 3); 2= Completed Grade 6 - Grade 7 (Std 4 - 5); 10= Completed Grade 8 - Grade 9 (Standard 6 - 7) i.e. some high school; 11= Completed Grade 10 - Grade 11 (Std. 8-9); 4= Completed Grade 12 (Std 10) i.e., high school; 5= Part of university/college/post-matric education; 6= Completed university/college/post-matric education; 111= Pre-school; 112= Class 1; 113= Class 2; 114= Class 3; 115= Class 4; 116= Class 5; 117= Class 6; 118= Class 7; 119= Class 8; 120= Form 1; 121= Form 2; 122= Form 3; 123= Form 4; 18= Tertiary Education; 100= Non-academic curriculum; 101= Alternative curriculum e.g. IGCSE; 999= Other; 888= Refused to answer; 777= Unknown

ElementDescription: If the child participant's caregiver's highest level of education is ''other'', please specify:
What is the child participant's caregiver's partner's highest level of education?
Notes: 0= No education; 1= Completed Grade 1 to Grade 5 (Sub A - Standard 3); 2= Completed Grade 6 - Grade 7 (Std 4 - 5); 10= Completed Grade 8 - Grade 9 (Standard 6 - 7) i.e. some high school; 11= Completed Grade 10 - Grade 11 (Std. 8-9); 4= Completed Grade 12 (Std 10) i.e., high school; 5= Part of university/college/post-matric education; 6= Completed university/college/post-matric education; 111= Pre-school; 112= Class 1; 113= Class 2; 114= Class 3; 115= Class 4; 116= Class 5; 117= Class 6; 118= Class 7; 119= Class 8; 120= Form 1; 121= Form 2; 122= Form 3; 123= Form 4; 18= Tertiary Education; 100= Non-academic curriculum; 101= Alternative curriculum e.g. IGCSE; 999= Other; 888= Refused to answer; 777= Unknown

ElementDescription: If child participant's caregiver's partner's highest level of education is ''other'', please specify:
What is the caregiver's current employment status?
Notes: 1= Employed (part or full time); 2= Self-employed; 3= Unemployed (looking for work); 4= Temporarily laid off; 5= Homemaker; 6= Student; 7= Illness/sickness; 8= Disabled and unable to work; 9= Retired; 10= Casual laborer; 11= Recently retrenched with package; 777= Unknown; 999= Other

ElementDescription: If the caregiver's current employment status is ''other'', please specify:
What is the child participant's caregiver's partner's current employment status?
Notes: 1= Employed (part or full time); 2= Self-employed; 3= Unemployed (looking for work); 4= Temporarily laid off; 5= Homemaker; 6= Student; 7= Illness/sickness; 8= Disabled and unable to work; 9= Retired; 10= Casual laborer; 11= Recently retrenched with package; 777= Unknown; 999= Other

ElementDescription: If the child participant's caregiver's partner's current employment status is ''other'', please specify.
What is the caregiver's current occupation? (Researcher to select response below based on answer)
Notes: 1= Professional/technical/managerial; 2= Clerical (e.g. administration= office support); 3= Sales and services; 4= Skilled manual labor; 5= Unskilled manual labor; 6= Domestic service; 7= Agriculture; 999= Other; 777= Unknown

ElementDescription: If the caregiver's current occupation is ''other'', please specify:
Does the child participant's caregiver receive any social assistance in the form of a government grant for yourself?
Do you ([i_sub_name]'s biological mother) receive any social assistance in the form of a government grant?
If the child participant's caregiver receives a government grant, what type? Disability grant
If the child participant's biological mother received any social assistance, what kind of grant? Check all that apply: Disability grant
If the child participant's caregiver receives a government grant, what type? Pension grant
If the child participant's caregiver receives a government grant, what type? South African Social Security Agency (SASSA) grant
If the child participant's caregiver receives a government grant, what type? Other
If the child participant's caregiver receives ''other'' government grant, describe:
Do the child participant's caregiver receive any social assistance in the form of a government grant for any of the children in your home/in your care?
Does the child participant's caregiver receive a government grant for children in his/her care or home? Childcare grant
If the child participant's biological mother received any social assistance, what kind of grant? Check all that apply: Childcare grant
Does the child participant's caregiver receive a government grant for children in his/her care or home? Care dependency grant
If the child participant's biological mother received any social assistance, what kind of grant? Check all that apply: Care dependency grant
Does the child participant's caregiver receive ''other'' government grant for children in his/her care or home?
If the child participant's caregiver receive ''other'' government grant for children in his/her care or home, describe:
If the child participant's caregiver receive a government grant for children in his/her care or home, for how many children does he/she get the childcare grant?
For how many children do you (participant's biological mother) receive the grant?
Does the child participant's caregiver's partner receive assistance in the form of a government grant for themselves?
Does the child participant's caregiver's partner receive a disability grant?
Does the child participant's caregiver's partner receive a pension grant?
Does the child participant's caregiver's partner receive a South African Social Security Agency (SASSA) grant?
Does the child participant's caregiver's partner receive any ''other'' grant?
If the child participant's caregiver's partner receives any ''other'' grant, describe.
Does the child participant's caregiver's partner receive social assistance in the form of a government grant for any children in their home or care?
Does the child participant's caregiver's partner receive social assistance in the form of a government grant for any children in their home or care? Childcare grant
Does the child participant's caregiver's partner receive social assistance in the form of a government grant for any children in their home or care? Care dependency grant
Does the child participant's caregiver's partner receive social assistance in the form of a government grant for any children in their home or care? Other
If the child participant's caregiver's partner receive ''other'' social assistance in the form of a government grant for any children in their home or care, describe.

If the child participant's caregiver's partner receive ''other'' social assistance in the form of a government grant for any children in their home or care, for how many children do they get the childcare grant?
What is the child participant's caregiver's average household income per month (i.e. average over the past 6 months)?
Notes: 1= Less than R1000 per month; 2= R1000-R5000 per month; 3= R5000-R10 000 per month; 4= More than R10 000 per month; 888= Prefer not to answer; 777= Unknown

ElementDescription: What is the current level of education is the child participant receiving?
Notes: 0= Never attended; 13= Creche; 14= Special Needs School (Foundation Phase); 15= Special Needs School (Middle Phase); 16= Special Needs School (Senior Phase); 17= Grade R; 1= Grade 1/Class 1; 2= Grade 2/Class 2; 3= Grade 3/Class 3; 4= Grade 4/Class 4; 5= Grade 5/Class 5; 6= Grade 6/Class 6; 7= Grade 7/Class 7/Junior Secondary 1; 8= Grade 8/Class 8/Junior Secondary 2; 9= Grade 9/Form 1/Junior Secondary 3; 10= Grade 10/Form 2/Senior Secondary 1; 11= Grade 11/Form 3/Senior Secondary 2; 12= Grade 12/Form 4/Senior Secondary 3; 20= Special Care Centre (Stimulation); 30= Home-schooling (Formal curriculum); 40= At home (No formal education); 100= Non-academic curriculum; 101= Alternative curriculum e.g. IGCSE; 102= Non-academic curriculum/Alternative curriculum (e.g. Training centre, practical, trade school); 111= Preschool; 999= Other; 777= Unknown

ElementDescription: Does the child participant receive any special support or assistance at their school?
If the child participant is receiving a non-academic/alternative curriculum, please provide more details:
If the child participant is receiving a non-academic/alternative curriculum, for how many years has the child received a non-academic/alternative curriculum?
If the child participant's current education level is ''other'', describe:
What type of school is the child participant attending?
Notes: 1= Mainstream school (admits children with special needs but does not have resources to support them); 5= Integrated school (has special unit section); 6= Inclusive school (similar to mainstream, but has facilities that support special needs); 2= Special Unit school; 3= Public School; 4= Private school; 999= Other; 777= Unknown

ElementDescription: If the child participant is attending ''other'' type of school, describe:
Has the child participant ever repeated any grades?
If the child participant has repeated any grades, which ones?
What is their first language at the child participant's school?
If the first language at the child participant's school is ''other'', specify:
How did the child participant do in their last exam for this subject? (i.e. in June or December)
How did the child participant's last exam result compare to the rest of their class at school? (As seen on their grade report)
How did the child participant do in their last exam for Maths (or Math Lit)? (i.e. in June or December)
How did the child participant's last Maths/Math Lit exam result compare to the rest of their class at school? (As seen on their grade report)
How many people normally live in the child participant's household?
How many adults (over the age of 18 years) live in the child participant's home?
How many children (ages 0-17) live in the child participant's home?
How many rooms are there in the child participant's home? *Note: Rooms can be any rooms or partitions within the home, & including kitchen, bathroom etc.
How many bedrooms are there in the child participant's home? I.e. how many rooms are designated for sleep?
How many people share the caregiver's bedroom (including the caregiver)?
Which of the following best describes the area in which the child participant lives?
Which of the following best describes the child participant's home (type of dwelling)?
Notes: 1= Shack; 2= Wendy House or backyard dwelling (temporary structure with no foundation); 3= House; 4= Flat; 5= Refugee centre/homeless shelter; 999= Other

ElementDescription: If the child participant lives in ''other'' type of dwelling, please specify:
Is the home where the child participant stays owned, rented, or an informal settlement plot?
Notes: 1= Own; 2= Rent; 3= Informal settlement plot (neither); 4= No rent ( with consent of owner); 5= No rent (squatting); 999= Other

ElementDescription: If the house where the child participant stays is by ''other'' arrangement (i.e., not owned or rented, etc.), describe:
Does the child participant's caregiver own any land other than the land where the primary residence is?
Does the child participant's household own the land on which the primary residence (house, flat, and shack) sits?
Notes: 1= Own; 2= Rent; 3= Informal settlement plot (neither); 4= No rent ( with consent of owner); 5= No rent (squatting); 999= Other

ElementDescription: Which of the following amenities does the child participant's caregiver's have in their home? None.
Which of the following amenities does the child participant's caregiver's have in their home? Tap or running (piped) water in the home
Which of the following amenities does the child participant's caregiver's have in their home? A flush toilet inside the main house
Which of the following amenities does the child participant's caregiver's have in their home? A built-in kitchen sink (with plumbing)
Which of the following amenities does the child participant's caregiver's have in their home? Electricity (e.g. plug points or electric lights
Which of the following amenities does the child participant's caregiver's have in their home? An electric stove or hotplate
Which of the following amenities does the child participant's caregiver's have in their home? Microwave
Which of the following amenities does the child participant's caregiver's have in their home? Fridge/freezer
Which of the following amenities does the child participant's caregiver's have in their home? TV (smart or analog)
Which of the following amenities does the child participant's caregiver's have in their home? Washing machine
Which of the following amenities does the child participant's caregiver's have in their home? Vacuum cleaner
Which of the following amenities does the child participant's caregiver's have in their home? Radio
Which of the following amenities does the child participant's caregiver's have in their home? A telephone (includes a cell phone)
Which of the following amenities does the child participant's caregiver's have in their home? Computer/laptop/tablet
Which of the following amenities does the child participant's caregiver's have in their home? At least one motor car or truck
Which of the following amenities does the child participant's caregiver's have in their home? A motorcycle or scooter
Which of the following amenities does the child participant's caregiver's have in their home? A bicycle
Which of the following amenities does the child participant's caregiver's have in their home? Domestic servant/help
Which of the following amenities does the child participant's caregiver's have in their home? Solar panels for electricity
Which of the following amenities does the child participant's caregiver's have in their home? Access to internet (phone/home)
What is the source of water for members of the household?
Notes: 1= Piped into dwelling; 2= Piped into compound or plot; 3= Public tap; 4= Open well in compound or plot; 5= Open public well; 6= Spring; 7= River; 8= Pond/lake; 9= Dam; 10= Rainwater; 11= Bottled water; 999= Other

ElementDescription: If the source of water for members of the household is ''other'', please specify.
How long does it take household members to go to the water source, get water and come back?
How frequently is water available from this source?
Notes: 1= Usually /always available; 2= Several hours per day; 3= Once or twice a week; 4= Infrequently

ElementDescription: What kind of toilet facilities does the household have?
Notes: 1= Flush toilet; 2= Traditional pit latrine; 3= Ventilated pit (VIP) latrine; 4= No facilities/bush/field; 999= Other

ElementDescription: If the household has ''other'' toilet facilities, please describe.
Does the household share this toilet with other households?
How many other households use this toilet?
What is the main material of the floor in the home?
Notes: 1= Earth/mud/dung/sand; 2= Wood planks; 3= Palm, bamboo; 4= Parquet/polished wood; 5= Vinyl or asphalt strips; 6= Ceramic tiles; 7= Carpet; 9= Cement; 999= Other

ElementDescription: If the main material of the home floor is ''other'', describe:
What is the main material of the roof in the home?
Notes: 1= Grass/thatch; 2= Tins, cans; 3= Corrugates iron; 4= Asbestos sheets; 5= Concrete; 6= Tiles; 999= Other

ElementDescription: If the main material of the roof in the home is ''other'', describe:
What type of windows are present in the home?
Notes: 1= Glass; 2= Shutters; 3= Wire mesh; 4= Open; 5= None; 999= Other

ElementDescription: If ''other'' type of windows are present in the home, describe:
Does the building in which the household lives need any repairs?
Notes: 1= Completely dilapidated shack; 2= Needs major repairs; 3= Needs no or minor repairs; 4= Being repaired now; 5= Under construction; 999= Other

ElementDescription: If the building in which the household lives need any ''other'' repairs, describe:
How many animals (e.g., sheep, goats, cows) does the household have?
Notes: 1= None; 2= Some (less than 5); 3= Many (more than 5); 777= Unknown

ElementDescription: How many chickens and ducks does the household have?
Notes: 1= None; 2= Some (less than 5); 3= Many (more than 5); 777= Unknown

ElementDescription: What type of fuel does the household mainly use for cooking?
Notes: 1= Electricity; 2= LPG/natural gas; 3= Biogas; 4= Paraffin/kerosene; 5= Coal, lignite; 6= Charcoal from wood; 7= Firewood/straw; 8= Dung; 999= Other

ElementDescription: If the household mainly uses ''other'' type of fuel for cooking, specify:
How does this household dispose of kitchen waste and trash?
Notes: 1= Regular collection by government; 2= Infrequent collection by government; 3= Pays for private collection; 4= Composted; 5= Dump, bury, burn in compound; 6= Dump in street/empty plot; 999= Other

ElementDescription: In what other manner does this household dispose waste?

Which of the following does the child's participant's caregiver's household own? Motorcycle/scooter?

Does any member of the household personally shop at supermarkets?
